author: Diana
text: A deeply moving experience. I planted a flower for my grandmother who lived through the occupation of Kherson, and it felt‚Ä¶ sacred. Thank you for creating this space where grief can grow into memory.

author: Luka
text: At first I thought it was just another archive. It's not. It's alive. The small acts - like lighting a candle - felt so human. I returned the next day and left a story for my brother. Powerful platform.

author: Natalia
text: I work with memory archives and have never seen something so gentle yet radical. The way stories are categorised thematically - with emotion at the centre - makes this more accessible than institutional archives. UX is beautiful.

author: James (UK)
text: As someone researching digital memorialisation, I found this project groundbreaking. The symbolic metaphors - especially planting flowers - bridge the cognitive and emotional in ways museums often fail to. It's poetic design. Bravo.

author: Pavlo
text: My cousin died last year. I didn't know how to express what I felt. Here, I found space - not to explain - but to share. To be part of something larger. Thank you for this digital memory garden.

author: Rali (Germany)
text: I came across this platform through a friend. I don't have a personal connection to Ukraine, but the stories touched me deeply. It's interactive, emotional, and globally relevant. Memory without borders.

author: Andrew
text: There's something sacred in the simplicity of this platform. The way it avoids spectacle, and instead gives quiet dignity to ordinary lives, is what makes it unforgettable.

author: Yeva
text: The candle I lit last week is still glowing in my heart. Thank you for creating a place where memory feels personal, collective, and full of warmth. We needed this.
